projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Acted by her Majesties Servants at the Phaenix in Drury Lane.
LONDON, Printed by I. D. for Iohn Williams, and F. Eglesfeild and are to be sould at the signe of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard. 1640.

list.head: The Persons of the Comedy.
list.item: Musidorus a Prince disguisd as a shepheard, lover of Pamela,
Pyrocles a Prince disguisd as an Amazon, lover of Philoclea.
Dametas a Rustick shepbeard and Guardian to Pamela and
Thumbe a miller Captaine of the Rebells.
Mopsa daughter to Dametas and Miso.

div.head: Actus Primus.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: SIr yet be gracious and heare them pray
That beg not for their owne, but for your safety
And honor of your state which eclipse
In your long darke and melancholly life,
We want you at the helme.
Our duties bind us tell you tis unnaturall
To bury your selfe alive, the people call
For their owne King to governe, the'ile forget
To pray for you if you continue thus
A stranger to em

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Or if not for them
Which every good king makes his care as being
A steward to provide them all earthly blessings,
Yet for the other part of you, our Mistris
That sleepes within your boosome, and not made
For such a conversation, returne
And warme your thoughts agen, about which all
Your servants like so many pictures gaze
At one another, but want motion, and take up
Roome ith Chambers of your Court, like Arras

sp.speaker: Philon
sp.l: Have a compassion to our daughters sir
Kill not your hopes in their restraint

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What cage
Can please the birds Created for skie freedome?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: How can you see your eldest child Pamel •
Spend her best part of time with such a rude
And ignorant hinde as the unbred Dametas?
A Lady of a high and active soule,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: No more

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Our duties bids us tell you this.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Hast thou forgotten
Philonax, or made a better glosse upon the Oracle?
Should we remaine in Court and let our daughters
Be in the sight of the admiring world
Reade that paper, and be not partiall Philonax

q.l: Thy eldest Care shall from thy carefull face
By princely meane be stolne and yet not lost
The younger shall with natur • es blisse embrace
An uncoch love, which nature hateth most
Both these themselves unto two such shall wed
That at a Beere, as at a barre shall plead
Why ile thee a living man they have made dead,
In thine owne seate a forralgne state shall sit
And ere that all these blowes thy head shall sit
Thou with thy wife adultery shall commit.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Canst blame me now? I should reioyce to see
My daughters happy mothers, but since their
Fate must be ripened with my blood, their pride
Rooted in my grave, and that untimely, tis
Wisdome to keepe 'em vrigins. I me resolu'd

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your queene and Ladies

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Vanish all discontent, Madam this place
Is emptie of all royall entertainement
Your worth may Challenge, but since fate allowes not
A Courtly life which best may answer your
High birth spirit, let your vertue guide you
To accept of what we tender,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This my Lord
Exceeds all merrit heere, it was the blisse
I aimd at to be acquainted with your goodnesse
I am your humble servant

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Such a title
Would rather become me, call me so Lady
And stile me above Kings, while I write yours

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: If your grace
Could call him from this life you'd melt the hearts
Of your subjects into prayers for you

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: I thanke your care but hees mexorable

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas deere princesse can you brooke these grove:
Has not a pallace something more of pleasure?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This shall be so to mee while tis n • y fathers,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I ha not seene a goodlier person, how

Came she admitted▪
〈◊〉 gracious with the king

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She has a charme to win from all the world

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: I have read the Amazons discrib'd so

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: These lippes had he that robd the dragon of
The golden Apples, but once seene he would
Ha wish'd to ha gatherd fruit heere, and esteemd
The gaine of one sweet kifse reward sufficient
For all his twelve hard labors

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sir your grace
Is pleasantly dispos'd to make my person
The subject of your mirth

sp.speaker: Bas
sp.l: And had those Creatures,
Booke blinded men, that dreame of other worlds
Tell of Elizian blessings, know the joyes
Are in your love they would have lost themselves
As I have done in speculation

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You make me blush to heare you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Theres no action
Dares so affright your blood, to talke, why Lady
There be those men and women great and good
Have found no shame in telling of their loves
Nay in the acting

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Give me leave to tell you
You are not modest if I understand you
A King give breath to such foule thoughts,
Your every action should be a starr
To guide your subjects, if you loose your piety
What wickednesse have they not heence for
If the devotion of your service be
To such a friend as Lust (as what name else
Can it deserve) let those whose hearts are lost
In sinne be tempted to dishonor, I
Abhor the thought, pardon me royall sir
I hope these are but trialls, if I thought
There had been such a levity in men
Thus to provoke you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Smooth thy brow agen
Or I shall neede no other punishment
Theres death too much in that; Philocle •

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: That name sounds all my comfort, and I must
Dispaire to tell her so, I was to blame
To be so peremptorie, would I were agen;
To shape my answer

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sir

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: That smile has put me out, oh looke thus ever
I was studying a new complement to begg
Thy excuse

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If you brought no offence there needes none sir
I must suppose your love, love is noble chaste

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: You will finde that hereafter, oh Zelmane.
Would thou couldst tell the meaning of my sighes

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You can expresse them.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Not I

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Choose another to speake them for you
And yet I want an or at or to tell you
What I would say, how ere I seeme

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Dost blesse me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Theres something wants a tongue, but for your passions
I should not thinke they would carry so much discord
To any virgin care delivered by a woman
There is a Way to meete a gentle audience.
At least not harsh disdaine, did your faire daughter
Philo • lea the volume of all sweetnes
Pleade halfe your suit, altho it borderd on
Something not altogether just, her tongue
Might perchance guide it, but I am confident
Your ends are noble

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Theres a lightening yet
Of comsort, happiest Lady I will study.
How to be worthy of this grace,

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: You are expected at the pastoralls

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: We take our leaves my Lord againe beseeching
Your pardon for our bouldnesse to reduce you
To your owne spheare of greatnes

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Doe you continue
Faithfull to your employments, and deserve of us
And of your Country; come Zelmane
There are some sports which you must grace

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I waite a servant to your commands

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Come sweete Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Come sweetest of thy sex

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Tis pittie nature.
Made thee not a man, this complement
Would then become you

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Mopsa you are to coy in my opinion
Tho I confesse your beauty may deserve
As much as any; Dorus tho he be
Your fathers servant, hee's a hansome shepheard
And not to be dispised.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Dispised, cannot a virgin love a young man I pray but she must dispise him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You should then with some smiles encourage him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Smoyles, let me alone to smoile, and something else when we are alone; if I thought he did not love me, I know What I know

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Alas poore man he cannot sleepe for you he saies,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay and I were a bed with him he should not sleepe so long as his eyes were open, I'de watch him for that, but doe you thinke my father would let us couple in matrimony as they say, he has never a sonne but I and I am his onely daughter.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
Make no scruple of that, if you can finde in your heart to love him, in the name of
• upid goe together, for ought I perceive your father houlds a good opinion of him, marry I know not how your mother is inclinde

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Whoope my mothers a scould

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Heres your sweete heart▪
Looke you make much of him, poore Gentleman
How love is abie to transport, who could
Expect so rich a guest in that poore dwelling
Oh how ere the windes compell him, or the streame
Into whose troubled waves he has launch'd forth
This way he steeres his love, yet I seeme ignorant.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: My deerest Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Deere; I never cost you anything

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I know not
At what expence of fortunes were I able
I should be willing to make purchase of you
But I'me sure you have already cost my heart
And yet I find yours made of Marble
Which neither pitty nor my prayers can soften,
Sweete Madam pleade for me, one gracious word
From you would make me happie, let one beame
Shoot fro • your eye, and it will strike a spring
Into that frozen peece of earth, and make it
A bower for love to spo •• in, 'tis in you
To unarme her noble heart, there's too much steele
And gentle love in vaine attempts to fasten
The softer blowes.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Mopsa take heed, your Shepheard can speake well
And if he be honest Menalcus brother
And heire, I know no reason why you should
Thinke scorne of him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: But for all his queint speeches Ile keepe my honestie
close enough I warrant you

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Why should you be so cruell, nature made
Your face the onely object of mans wonder

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Does my face looke like a flapiack?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Is't possible there can be a soule so hard
So vnrelenting dwell in that faire body?
If you knew the truth of my affection and with what
Religion it lookes upon your vertues.
'T would teach your eye compassion, gracious princesse
Let the distressed Dorus gaine this mercy
From you that with the blessednes of your
White hand reaching to Mopsa this poore toy
Which late I found my love may cherish hope
At last to be accepted

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh fine what's that Madam?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: You must yet be a little coy to receive it

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: I wonot have it, and he wou • d give it me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: A rich Iewell the figure of a Crabfish

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The trew emblem of my loves pace which lookes another way
To that it moves, she cannot but distinguish
Whether I would direct my heart, her eyes
Are fixt upon't, and my poore soule could heere
Star-gaze for ever

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: By force not choyce—all his desire is Mopsa
Tow in your grace by my presenting it

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Ile take it for your sake, I wonot thanke him

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has no apprehension, with what
A calme and carelesse temper does she give it

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Madam Pamela, oh are you there, tis well

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: I me out of breath, let me walke my selfe a little

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What haste does tire you?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Tire me, I am no woman, keepe your tires to your selfe
Nor am I Pericles prince of Tyre.

sp.speaker: Pam
sp.l: I doe beleeve it, heaven make you an honest subject,
For a wise one, I dispaire to see you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Am I the subject of your talke? But I give you leave to use your tongue, y'are a woman, Dorus what make you ideling heere? is the field dung'd as I gave Directions, and the Calfe with the white face brought home to execution?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I was carefull in my dutie.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Beleeve me governor there is much hope of your servant,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I, governour becomes you, I like it well when you carry an M vnder your girdle, our govern, he will do pritty well in time, when I have taught him the manners of the Cart, he begins whistle in tune already, and can curry favour with the horses, but now I remember my selfe I forgot what I came hither for, oh dee heare tis the king your fathers pleasure and mine, that you make haste to the lodge.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ile attend

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There will be gambolls to please my Lady Salamandor.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Zelmane you would say.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I care not what you say, but if you meane to heare the Dances and see the fine songs you must make haste; Dorus you shall have leave to shake your heeles, looke you be mannerly, and shew a cleane calf, Mopsa whats that you ha got there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: A fine thing our man Dorus game, he saies tis a fish

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Tis a Codds head ist not, much came how you by this

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Following the plow I found it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
Would all my acres were sowne with such, vmh dores he throw his stones at thee already, well set forward, if thou diest before me Dorus Ile make some body mine heire; if I out live thee, I wonot say what legacie I meane to bestow upon
• hee, Continue thy dutie Dorus and follow me with a reverence.

div.stage: Enter Basilius, Gynecia, Pyrocles, Pamela, Philoclea, Mopsa, Musidorus, a Shepheards.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ladies our revells wants the state and glory
With which the Court delights might charme your senses
Our sceane is naturall but interpret fairely 'twas meant
A cure for times sicke feathers, and your mirth,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Virtue will prompt you to
Accept what was intended for your service
Yet 'tis within my wishes to salute you
With other testimony of your welcome.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I kisse your white hand,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Every touch conveies a firce spirit through my blood
I shall betray my suffering, and through my eyes
Let out my heart, Philoclea sit

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Wilt please you rest your selfe?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Dwell heere for ever
I am now but one degree from heaven,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Since you imagine you are so neere, it is no sin
I hope to entreate you staie with us a little, I would
Wish tho to make you blest with too hastie a remove▪

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You are all goodnes, oh that I durst but give
Some liberty to my imprisoned thoughts

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Philoclea you hinder the faire stranger.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Pardon me that am her trouble rather

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: She should want vertue to call you so, but they begin
Dametas is the steward for this dayes mirth I see.
And meanes to bring in the first course.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Cupid is blind some say but there are lyes
Abroad, for Cupid never wanted eyes
He is a Deity with bow and arrow
And he can pirce with it the very marrow
And never hurt the bones, ist not a wonder.
That flaming Ice should cut mans heart in sunder,
sp.stage: Enter Cupid Shepheard Musedo. Mopsa and Miso:
sp.l: Behold the Dandiprat that liv'dat Court.
But is come hether to make country sport
A wooddy god; but yet a very Coult
Among the maids who feele his furious boult.
Now Cupid speake thy selfe or while they play
Sing if you please I ha'not more to say.
Cupid. Tell me tydings of my mother.
Shepheards, and be Cupids brother
Downe from heaven we came together
With swanns speede came she not hither?
But what Lady have I spyde.
Iust so was my mother eyde
Such her smiles wherein I dwelt
In those lips have I been felt
Those the pillowes of her brest
Which gave Cupid so much rest.
'Tis she 'tis she make holyday
Shepheards Carroll Dance and play
'Tis Venus it can be no other
Cupid now has found his mother

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: This was your poetrie, Zelmane
You are beholding to him, he would make
You another I see,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Gynecia

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I am silent—Philoclea is too neere
I am not well'oth sudden, breake off your mirth

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: What ayles Gynecia?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My heart is sicke

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Forbid it heaven

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Retire, come my Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I attend

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Looke to your charge Dametas

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I have a pretious time; will you pace it governor?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Trot, amble or gallop Ile runne in your hand Lady.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Come Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Your humble servant

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Thou art cruell.
To an innocent bosome love, there is no way
Within thy power to save me, oh Philoclea
Where shall I coole my heart, oh if there be
One shaft can kill, good Cupid ayme at me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I warrant you Madam they shall have good lucke if they whisper together in my hearing,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Where is Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: In some of the Arbours, she tooke a Lute abroad with her but I left Philoclea with her father

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Prithee be carefull and watch them well good Miso

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: They shano't scape me, Ile watch their waters narrowlie I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I see through his disguise 'tis so, and love
Hath put this shape on him for Philoclea,
In what a miserable flame I burne!
Zelmane thou hast stolne.
My vertue from me, I ha'not power to thinke
A harmelesse thought, ha Musique,
sp.stage: Musique. Song Pyrocles sings Enter Pyroclos.
sp.l: From whence breathes that sound? it is Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What miserable accident brought her?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Madam I hope you'l pardon
The trespasse of a rude hand and voyce, I meant not
This for your curious care

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: 'Twas harmony

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: It was no light aire I'me sure

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Indeede it carried something me thought
Of sorrowes descant, I heard love i'nt too
Who is so happie to deserve a memorie
But in your sigh, come whoe's your servant?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have no servant.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay then I see you can dissemble, my husband

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Madam I hope

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay I am so farre from Iealosie I should not
Be angry to see you both a bed together

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How Madam

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Why I can love you too, come thou sha't be my bed-fellow

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am not worthy

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Beleeve me I could take as much delight
In thy imbraces as my husbands, why
Are we so nice to one annother, I
Am a woman, are not you so too?
Why should we not be bould then, I have a mind
To call thee Mistris, Yes and Ile disguise.
My selfe in some queint shape to court thy love:

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Disguise

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay do not blush: thou shalt be a man

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Your discourse appeares.
Strange to me Madam.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: As you would to me
And yet you may as easily perceive
Gynecias mindas I distinguish you
Through all your clouds, Cupid doth dictate rarely.
To those that come to schoole to him, instruct
With hansome shaddowes to deceive the eye
But cannot change my substance, I have a sense
Can looke beyond the superficiall barke
Come y'are transparen't

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Madam what dee meane?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What meanes Zelmane to be igonrant
When a Queene pleads for love, my heart will not
Allow more circumstance; doe not question
How you became reveald, but pitty her
Whose boosome is tormented with those fires
Thy smiles the only greater flame can quench.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Pray heaven, you have your perfect senses.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Then I must be plainer, and be witnesse love
I am compell'd, be witnesse modesty,
I now must blush for thee more then my selfe,
A man, and be so cruell to a Lady
Zelmane either give consent I shall
be welcome to thee, or I vow by heaven
To tell Basilius what thou art, I have
Patience to let him court thee as a woman
But when he see's his love abuse his privacie
And daughters so dishonor'd hadst thou a thousand
Lives they were all forfeited by this
So desperate in trusion, thinke uppon't
A woman I have lost thee, wheither will
Thetempest of my fate inforce my tongue
Yet be thou kinde Zelmane if thou takst
A glory in my suffering, Philoclea
Does that name startle you? Philoclea
My rivall now

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Your rivall

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Come I am familliar with every thought
Your deere saint shall repent it, for this hand
Shall take againe the unluckie life I gave her:
Turne not Gynecia fury

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am lost
In the same minute I am found, I prithee
Doe not forsake me heart, I never had
More use of thee, great Queene can you forgive?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: And aske thy pardon, but beleeve me t'was
Your strangenes did compell me to this language

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I never thought that pitty of annother
Could be a reason to betray my selfe
But you have throughly charm'd me, and I must
Deliver up my thoughts, the truth is Madam
I am a man, and if you dare beleeve me
A prince, I must confesse beside Gynecia
Since I came heither I have had some sprinckling of
I know not what affection to Philoclea
For how could I imagine such a blessednes
From you, but if you mocke not

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Ioyes reward your pittie
Oh pardon the over chardg'd Gynecia
Whose error may be yet made more excusable
By the immortall name of love

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This grace is worth more then Zelmane, and yet I
Have nothing but my selfe to give you for it
A small but free guift, bestow me as you please

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My soule is narrow to receive this wide blessing.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: But me must be wise
It were not safe to be observ,'d stand I
Discover'd to none else?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: To none

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Then know
I want no apprehension of what
True lovers would desire, but your honor is
My owne, if shortly to secure 'em both
You let me study an opportunity
Ile bring your wishes home, and blesse my starrs
That pointed me the glorious fate, we are
Already interrupted

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Doe this my deere Philoclea, and leave
My cares to thee, Ile call Gynecia
Away, and leave you both together, how
Faireth the best Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Still your servant

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Gynecia.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I cannot rule my eyes they will betray
My cunning to Gynecia if she goe not
Hence quickly

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How is it with my vertuous Amazon?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Philoclea

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Let her alone, they have some busines sweete

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What busines can they have together?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Why art thou troubled, thou would'st be jealous
Of me I see, were I in privat with her,
Come let 'em alone a while

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Stay you and spare not I would imploy Philoclea

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: You shall obay me now, I prithee walke

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.l: My father sweete Zelmane to whose command
I owe my life

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: First let me give my life
Vp to these lips, and take a new one from
This kisse, oh deere Philoclea containe
All other breath I know thy fathers minde
Already, and must now beseech thy patience
To a short story which I must deliver
Or dy before thee, if it be within
My desteny to be condem'd by you
At least know whom you sentence; I am

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What? I feare not well

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Cannot your eyes discover me, have I a shrowd
To hide me from Philoclea? did the kisse
I gave thee last convey no secret to thee?
There was a spirit in my lip assur'd me.
To save the tedious trouble of my language.
I heard it whisper something, did it not?
I would be fraine undone

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Good heaven forbid

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You wonot understand me yet Philoclea
Then Ile undoe my selfe, I am not what
I seeme Zelmane; but—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: P • .
sp.l: A thing not worth the name, if you frowne on me, a man

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A man, good heaven •

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have tould you all the worst
If it be no offence to name a prince
Whose memory your owne breath oft hath sweeten'd
I dare be call'd Pyroclos of Macedon
Transform'd by loving your faire selfe to this
Feminine shape, if now I have not sinn'd
Above forgivenes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh Philoclea
Come not too neere I charge you; I would chide.
But dare not, would you had not tould me this
Indeed you were to blame, I must not heare you
Excuse your selfe

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: She must not leave me thus
But she returnes

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have lost my selfe already,
And love is but a blinde guide to direct
My virgin steps, I faine would reply something
But feele a tremblinge in my voyce, Zelmane
My father, what account shall I give him
I have said nothinge he commanded

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: She smiles

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: My Lord I see you can use the advantage
And I did arme you against my selfe; I did not
Thinke when I advis'd you make Philoclea
Your advocate, she could so much have wonne
Vpon me, but my counsell has betray'd me,
Pray thinke me not immodest, if my words
Doe fall too rudely from me, your faire daughter
Whose tongue would lay a charme uppon the gods,
Hath gain'd all this.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: The gods reward her for it

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was this his plot?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A thousand blessings overtake my child
But not a word, not a word Philoclea
To thy mother

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have learnt my duty sir

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Beshrew your haste

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Remove, convey thy selfe away deere girle, Ile follow

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My heart is full, and tho my tongue denies
Him farwell, he may reade it in my eye.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I knew thou couldst not choose at last but give
My heart an audience; I am not my selfe
With the imagination

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Of any thing; come I allow thee modest, it is not fit we should say our pleasures, sweete but act them

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You are to violent my Lord, I shall
Repent my freedome, if you give no limit
To your desires, if you doe love your servant,
Husband your flame that it may last

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: It shall
Pardon me deere Zelmane, I have a stock
Of blood, tho you may thinke it could is high
And active as the veynes of promising youth
I weare this snow but a disguise

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Poore winter,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: My haires are black at roote, and shall grow up
Faire as the Ebony and curle themselues
Into a thousand pretty caves for love
It selfe to sit that best delights in darknes

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This will be strange.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'Tis you that worke these miracles
Vpon Basilius, as I came heither
I felt a score of yeares drop off, which hung
Vpon my locks

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: A score of haires you meane: tis molting time
Containe your selfe a while, you have
A jealous queene, and yet it goes against my Conscience
To wrong so sweete a Lady, pray my Lord
Thinke better ont

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: This Does inflame me more
Be not so cruell to remember her
Thou must preserve my life.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well I ha thought a way
Shall perfect all without suspition
There is a cave hard by which nature made
Intending well to lovers, thether will I
With licence of your grace pretending
To exercise a few dayes some devotions
We Amazons have obligation to
At some convenient houre.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: May I come to thee

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Ile give you notice in some evening

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Zelmane now thou dostravish me

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You may with ease secure all at the lodge

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Most excellent

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I imagin sir the rest but doe not come till I desire you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Be not tedious then, I will prepare all this

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I hope you doe not
Conclude me impudent that I encline
To doe this for you, by my hopes of a blest
Eternitie nor love nor lust ere tempted
My thoughts to yeild thus much to any man
Be carefull of my honor.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Oh devine Zelmane keepe my soule.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Philoclea mine

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Oh my deere Pyrocles

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How ist deere Cozen

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Never till now could you salute me happy
The gods have beene propitious

sp.speaker: Pyr,
sp.l: Will she know thee yet?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: There's nothing wants to make me perfect blest
But to heare thee pronounce thy love as fortunate
The envious clouds which interpose themselves
Like a darke Curtaine ore Pamelas face.
Are drawne away and I enjoy her smile
She does beleeve my proofes, sweetely excusing
Her long neglect, and promiseth as much
As I dare aske: sheel' trust me with her person
I want but opportunity to deceive
Our waking Dragons;—and in good time Dametas.
Away you shall know all my fate hereafter,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I joy in thy successe, pray thou for mine.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Where is this rascall Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Whether were I best to tell the King ont first or seeke out
Dametas, hee'l never be able to spend it, there may be gold
Enough to purchase halfe Arcadia

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Vmh, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Ile seeke him out at all adventures; oh s • r, pray is this
Gold—and this and this?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ha gold, yes very good gold, where hadst it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You shall heare more hereafter

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Dorus, honest Dorus, put on thy hat, where where, hadst it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Did you never heare of one Aristomines?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: He was banish'd Arcadia

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Was he rich

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Infinite rich, so rich

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: 'Tis so, belike he there had all his treasure

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: What treasure, where i'st honest Dorus tell me

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You are my Master and may be my Father

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: My sonne Dorus, Mopsa is thine, and she were made of as pure gold as this, thou shouldst touch her, and melt her

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Well I see it was ordained to make you rich
In dutie Ile discover it, and yet—

sp.speaker: Drm.
sp.l: Out with it good Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Well—sitting beneath an oake that shall be namelesse
I chanc'd to turne up some turff with my mole-spade

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: With thy mole spade, what then

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I saw a yellow brightnes peeping out oth' ground, which
when I came to examine I pr • v'd this mettall, I this was the first,
y'are sure 'tis gold, you shall pardon me for the rest but if these
will do you any pleasure, or twentie more

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Nay good honest Dorus proceede.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Why the truth is I suspect where a great treasure has been
Long buried, these it seemes were scatter'd when the rest
Went to the pit-hole.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: But where is this place good Dorus? thou hast no more
About thee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: No but if you please to furnish me with tooles Ile trye
The bottome; I digd till I came to a stone, whose inscription
Promis'd something worth a mans labour

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Did it sound

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Melodiously a goulden tune

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Where, where, thou maist tell me thou knowest I
Am secret

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: For Mopsa sake I will reveal't, you know▪
The oake where you first met me

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ha very well

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: On the right side of that same spreading tree
Lies all this riches

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: As th'art honest

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: As I hope to be deere Mopsa's husba • d, Ile get strong tooles
And bring you better proofe

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Stay Dorus stay, let me see
As I intend to be your father Dorus
And so in Mopsas name make you my heire
Of all my wealth, good Dorus I am yet
Till things and things be done your Master Dorus
Beside that ground is mine, the Oake is mine
Where under lies this treasure, I am Lord
Lord of the soyle my Dorus, of the soile
I am content to be a ground for you
To build to hopes on Dorus, but my ground
No man shall dig or build on but my selfe
On such as this, be there a myne
Of Coyne or vncoyne mettall it is mine
All may be yours annother day my Dorus.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I know my duty sir and cannot thinke
The gods had ere a lotted my free mind
To serve you but for some strange end

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: In this thou shewst it, keepe all close, not a word Dorus, I take no leave be carefull my good Dorus of my young Madam, 'tis a charge I turne over to thee, over looke her well.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I meane to doe it doubly

sp.speaker: Dam
sp.l: How, ha you a duble meaning?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I meane with double care

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Honest Dorus 'tis the last service I shall put thee to

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I hope so to

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Now to the Oake my golden land marke

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Load a horse with tooles sir

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Mattocks and shovells

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hookes and ladders.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Spade and Pickaxes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Ropes and daggers; youl have no helpe

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: No no, a mans owne toyle
Sweeter the profit makes in his owne soyle.

sp.speaker: Mus
sp.l: Goe thy wayes for the Lord a'th soyle
Theres one blocke out a'th way the golden flie,
Has caught this trowte, my jealous Mistris I
Hope she ore heard not

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Oh that my eares had beene long enough to have heard some of there pretious Knaverie

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It were but charitie to tell her on't, little does my Mistris Thinke what a flesh flie my Master is,

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: What saies the Knave

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Tho she be a little stricken in yeares she is hansome enough
For as good a man as Dametas, and he to runne neighing
A this fashion after a blowse, and then put me to make excuse
For him, 'tis not right.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Oh fidious Rascall, I thought there was some roguerie,
Dorus as thou com'st of a woman tell me

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: What forsooth

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Oh naughty man to vse an honost woman the wrong way thus, have I beene married so many yeares, and carried my selfe like his lawfull wife uprising and downe lying as they say, so even and jumpe with his desires to be thus handled, but Ile be reveng'd it shall fall heavie vpon his head for this I warrant him, nay I did alwaies suspect him for a co • t

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What meane you forsooth,

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Come I ouer-heard somewhat to my griefe, and therefore leaue your bogling and your trim tram tricks you must not flap me oth mouth with fleering and with flams whilst he

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Claps vp another betwixt the—a ha mistris mistris but you say you overheard, and therefore if you know whether he is gone you may come two houres hence time enough to prevent the blow.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: If thou lookest to have my daughter with, marke what I say

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: With fathers marke and mothers marke, and every mark about her

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: If you conceale any thing in this case, thou knowst no case of her, nay tho thy teeth water out the liquor of thy life, thou shouldst not get a bit, the worst bit of her.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Be more charitable

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Or if thou chance to get her gainst my will ile teach her a tricke of the mother shall make thee curse her and all the brood she came one,

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What is Charita to me, I know you heard him name her.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Charita.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I will discharge my conscience and yet if you overheard us without my telling, you know where hee appointed to meet her this evening at Mantinea at her fathers in Ondemion streete,

sp.speaker: Mis
sp.p: Ondemion street?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I doe not betray him now if you provide so happily to take em at it mistris at it.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: I at it, how I itch to be at it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Saddle your mare.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: They shal not scape with halfe an eie betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I have given her the bells and she will flye to the devill —here comes the tother I ha given her phisicke already fit for her constitution and now it works.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: How comes it Mopsa that you are so taken
So lifted up with high conceit?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Who I

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Yes Mapsa you, dee thinke I cannot Iudge
By outward gestures and your lookes what joy
Doth inwardly possesse you

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Who me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Yes you againe, and it were not over bouldnesse
To request some knowledge of the cause

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Rest you content; you are a Princesse borne I might have beene so to, some body may be a Queene before you, make what you can of that

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Oh fate how's this

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There is a tree, and there is things worth wishing, and some may wish and wishes may be had make what you can of that too

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: To my wish it workes

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: But Mopsa may I not beseech a word
That may be to my understanding

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: You may know more hereafter, but till then I must presume upon your Princely patience to keepe your Chamber, it is now my raigne and doe not dare to follow

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Not I, when you are drawne up to majesty
I can but wish you graciously would then
Remember the obedience of your handmaide
That first submits her selfe to your Command.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I faith I will Pamela, and reward it, goe in sweete Lady, on my Royall word I will,

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has spide me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Happy Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: What will my Mopsa say when she has climb'd
The tree of happines?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I I the tree, when I climbe that tree, hony Dorus tell me it over agen, my deere bird what did Iupiter to Apollo.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Vpon some falling out I tould you Jupiter threw Apollo out of heaven and his deitie taken away he was faine to live upon the earth and keepe Admetas Cattell, in the time of his service being sent to fetch abreede of beasts out of Arcadia, in this very desart he grew fainte and wearie; and would needs rest himselfe in the boughes of an Ashen tree.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: The tree we wot of; on sweete bird

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Apollo in that tree calling to minde his quarrell with Iupiter became very sorrowfull, and pittifully complayning to his father, asking him mercie for having offended him was from that tree receiv'd into his golden spheare, and made a god agen

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh brave

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Having the perfect nature of a god
Never to be ingratefull he then granted
A double life to Admetas, and because
That tree was chappell of his happy prayers
To it he gave this quality

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Now it comes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: That whosoever sat downe in that tree
In like estate and sort as he did then

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh now now now.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Should forthwith have there their wish

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh the tree, the tree, the tree

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: The king vnderstood thus much by Oracle; and tried himselfe but being neither heardman as then Apollo was, nor of the race which is necessarie, delivered this secret to your father but made him sweare to wish by his direction; for his owne benefit Dametas tould it me, and is now gon to furnish himselfe with a scarlet Cloake for in that he must be mufled just as Apollo was, I might now prevent'em all and be king my selfe, but what have I to wish more then the love of Mopsa which since without more charming force you yeild me; Ile fit you with a cloake and then wish what you will your selfe

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Ile be Queene or Apollo shall never looke me in the face agen, quickly sweet Dorus, come muffle me I long to be Queene,
and my father shall aske me blessing.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: COme my masters let us be resolute, is there any man That will justifie himselfe to be sober amongst us?
No hang sobriety

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: We must be valiant, the King I say agen has left us, and since He scornes our company for my part I scorne to be his subject
I I scorne subjects, Ile be an Emperor
It is time to looke into the government, none but Gentlemen are of his Counsell, I see no reason since the Countrie is 'ours but we should have a stroake in the state.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: That was bravely spoke my bully, stroke, heby Mars his Gauntlet spoke like a souldier, I doe not like the Carriage of the secret Counsells
Nor I nor any body

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Take heede my Masters
Lets heare Thumbe the Miller

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: We met together to drinke in honour of the Kings birthday and tho we have tickled the Cannikins, let vs be merrie and wise that's my opinion, no treason, the King is an honest Gentleman, and so is the Queene.
Very wisely spoken.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But shall be govern'd by Philonax':
Who knowes but he has made away the King

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Made away the King, who honest Basilius, aske the King who has made him away, by this hand if I thought they had made him away I would make some body away, tho I hang'd fort, but neighbors for my owne part I will joyne with you in any thing that is honorable, dee marke honorable; but I say still I am cleare of opinion it is not a misse to be merry and wise Gentlemen, my name's Thumbe,
I Tom

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And Ile be a your side howsoever
A great spirit

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shall I speake for you

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: I I agreed you shall be Captaine

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why then let me alone; I will know a reason why hee has left the government without our consents to depose him, 'tis wisely spoken mybrave men 'oth common-wealth, we will have other lawes and the old shall be executed
I I hang the old ones
'Tis a discredit for any subjects as we are to have a King as if we were not able to governe our selves

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: Stroake up thy forehead thou wert borne to be a statesman, Be rul'd by me and weel have no justice in Arcadia
How

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No justice, why should we loose our liberties, and being free men, upon any occasion suffer our selues to be bound over

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Gentlemen Citizens it were very good you would take into your consideration the statute against drunkennesse

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: It shall be lawfull for any man to be drunke without forfeiting or paying anything to the poore

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Very good, every man drinke away his estate, and then charity begins at home,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No man shall marrie
That's worse then the statute against two wives

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: For every woman shall be common
Every woman common, what shall we doe withall the proper women in Arcadia

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: They shall be common too
Oh'rare, and what shall we doe withall the prisons

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Set'em a fire 'twill warme the Citie when there is cold doings
What with the prisoners

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Put'em in possession of their creditors lands, they are the only men fit for authority; for no men are us'd worst, and they will know the better to domineere, nay weel have admirable lawes, but who shall be this Embassador to the King
Me me choose me Captaine,

sp.speaker: Th •
sp.p: Choose you Captaine, Haberdasher of small wares, choose you a Capon, Ile be the Embassador, ever while you live let a bould man be embassador, and one that has a braine, I will not be mealc mouth'd.
Well said Miller

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And because we will be wise

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I I be merry and wise, ever while you live be sober and discreete.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Say weattend heere to do our duties
Duties oh base

sp.speaker: Cap •
sp.p: Say so we must, heel not come forth else
What if I could his highnes there was a dance to be presented we are furnish'd with our noise still

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I I, I doe love this noise withall my heart

Excellent, get you behind the trees with your instruments, and tune 'em ready, the new friske we danc'd at Enispies to day will serve rarely as the Prologue, away; but Captaine what shall we doe with the Kings daughters

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ile have one

sp.l: And Ile ha the tother our Captaine shall ha the Queene

sp.p: And what shall we have.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thereare Ladies about the Court will content you

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: I will have both the Kings daughters, and he that speakes against it—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thumbe valiant Thumbe, all spirit no mutinie no mutinie all of a faction together by the eares for a peece of venison

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I will have both the Kings daughters or else I shall not be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: First let vs know the Kings resolution, and if we like not our conditions, the hares a foote; and every man take what course he please in my Lords Parke Enter Basilius, Gynecia, Pyrocles, and Philoclea. But stay the King vmh
Speake Captaine

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: If it please your Maiesty, what was it resolu'd upon
Hees out, let me come to him, prithee doe thou tell him thy minde, that delicome wench has made my teeth water

And drown'd thy tongue, a Company of bashfull shrimpes;
if I but open my mouth, I say no more

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: King, by your leave; which is the King, my eyes twinckle, we have beene playing the good fellowes to celebrate your majesticall birth day, will your grace see a song
A dance

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Or a dance, alls one, our seete are in tune, strike up behinde the tree, you are the King and I am the Miller, ther's all the difference, sweete Ladies my name is Thumbe

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: This is rudenesse

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Pardon their simplicity

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Ile have that wench she lookes like Hercules, Omnes, Stand

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: We have intorrogations points to put to you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Treason, treason,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Barborous Villaines

div.stage:
Basilius runnes in, a bell rings, Philoclea, and Gynecia hid •
themselves, Pyrocles fights with them, Basilius comes in with a two handed sword, after some skirmish Enter Philonax and Calander with a guard the Rebells beaten off.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Where is Philoclea

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Heere art thou not hurt Zelmane.
My soule at every stroake made against thee
Was leaving my palebody

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Deere Madam are you safe

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: I thinke I ha pepper'd some of 'em, Philonax 'twas not amisse you came, but Zelmane and I should have made a shift

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: You alone my Lord, were an army against such reeling vallors, I did not thinke you could ha bestir'd your selfe so well

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p:
And I were in an other place alone with thee I could best •
my selfe better

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I would you would consider yet to quit
This dangerous kinde of life

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Had not the valiant Amazon it seemes, defenc'd your person
Ere the troopes ariv'd, it might have prov'd too fatall

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: He plaide the man indeede, the King is troubled
And thinks me Iealous of him, lasse old man

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: No more
Waite upon our Queene and daughter, weel follow
I am wounded

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: By thee Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I see your passions are the same and I
This might resolue to waite for you in the Cave
If you when your Gynecia is a bed
And fast a sleepe, (be sure of that) will please
To put your selfe to a short travell, I
Shall not expresse your welcome, but

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Deere as my soule I apprehend my comfort
One kisse in earnest of the million
Thou shalt receive, but carrie it close Zelmane

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: This is the Tree

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh let me kisse it toes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Best loose no time

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Haile upon haile sweete tree, Crowne thee and all thy wishes, Oh Dorus up womee Dorus, up womee, up womee, up womee Dorus, teach mee to clymbe the right way prithee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: You must be muffled in the cloake, so now remember your instructions, make first your invocation to Apollo as I tould you, which being done, imploy your minde withall devotion to his deity, untill you heare a voyce call three times on you by your name, tho you should thinke your father mother Pamela or my selfe talke to you answer not they are spirits that would delude.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Vnder three Mopsas Ile not talke to 'em, Ile not be cozend

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold there and youl' be happy

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Ile aske a king to my hus • and, and thou shalt be he

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Your invocation.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Into the greate eares of Apollo
Now let my invocation hollow
Oh thou that lightest all the day
For some to worke and some to play
By owle light now
Incline a gracious eare to me
Thus▪ muffled in thy wishing 〈◊〉
Singing whoope whoope who ••
And pardon this my subtilty
That I deceive the passers by
I in this bough
Doe use the accentes of that fowle
Because I would be thought an Owle
With whoope whoope whoee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has done her invocation

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Can she not heare us

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: She shall heare us, but I have taken order with her eyes and understanding too, sheel not beleeve us, thou lovely bird Madge howlet

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: That's a spirit in the voyce of Dorus, but Ile not answer.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: See Dorus and Pamela both are heere
Whilst old Dametas Miso, and their deere
Daughter are stragled forth, they both together
Are taking now their flight, and who knowes whether

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: This is too plaine

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Oh cunning Divells, but Ile not heare nor speake a sillable

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: If thou canst finde a tongue to tell Dametas,
Make knowne unto his wisdome he is gull'd
Take courage Madam the way lies faire before us
And abarque already prepard cries come a bour'd
Farewell Howlet

div.stage: Exeunt Musidorus and Pamela Dametas sings within

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whoope whoope whooe—Hey I heare another singing spirit in my fathers voyce, bee't Apollo himselfe, under three Mopsas Ile not speake

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: This is the tree, and heere the earth is broken
The certaine signe left by my trusty Dorus
The mouth of the rich treasure I salute thee
And kisse the hole from whence shall come my gold
Which being done blithly to worke I fall
My hand is in the moone-shine, and up goes all

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Whoope whoope, whooe

sp.speaker: Dam,
sp.p: What's that; an Owle, good Mis •• is Margerie I am busie Art thou poore and wouldst thou be advanc'd by wealth to Dignity doe not thinke it then vnmeete to stoope with hands beneath thy feete 'Tis not with hand over head to be found no • o thou must stoope though thou holdst up thy poope and grable for't in ground Ha what's this, my hand is in the Hony pot I thinke, vmh vmh I doe not like the softnes, I did groape for harder stuffe, if this be gold 'tis liquid, and yet too thicke to be potable as they say, it has a kinde of weft me thinks if I have not lost a sence upon the sudden, I smell, call you this gold finding

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I have an extreame list now so I have saving your presence, divell would restore your sence

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
What's this, a written parchment this may be the inventory of all the treasure.
Who hath his hire hath well his labor plac'd
Earth thou didst seeke, and store of earth thou hast
Howe's this

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whoope whoope whooe

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: As sure as this is my owne nose, I am stinkingly abus'd

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Ha ha ha,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Can Madge Howlets laugh, that laugh was like my Daughter Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There's one time, againe againe sweete Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: 'Tis her voyce what makes she there, now the dread vengeance of my deere fatherly curse, light over th'wart thee thou aukeward helding Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There's two times, Mopsa once more and 'tis Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you not answer in the Divells name Mopsa I say, oh are you come

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Yes yes divine Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile unhoode yee wheres Pamela

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Thanke your Deitie

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Speake now and tell me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Answer my wishes as 'thou art Phebus, as thou art Apollo tho in the likenesse of the Clowne my father, grant me my wishes first, I aske a King to be my husband.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What talkest thou of a King; the King will hang thy father if Pamela be gon

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Let him be hang'd I care not, but let Dorus be a King, and let him be my husband good Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Shee's starke staring mad, hast thou forgot thy father, where is thy wit

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I doe not aske for wit, I tell thee, let me have a sufficient husband and let him be a King

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thou shal't have thy bellifull of husbands

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Oh that, that, that

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.l: Ile at you both thou ribald villaine and thou harlot

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Miso my spouse falne mad too
Thou wot not beate thy mother

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Oh me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I defie her and thee and thou beest not Apollo,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh who has gulled us all, deere Miso, tender Mopsa heare me, before I open my mouth, art not thou Miso, and thou my daughter Mopsa, oh we are all vndone we are all vndone

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Are not you god Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: No as ever I hope to see him or any of his fellowes in the face againe, I am mortall Dametas and I thinke thy father, I am sure I am by thy mothers side, where is Pamela all this while, whoes at home.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As sure as you are my father and you my mother, theres No body at home

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Shee's gon, shee's gon

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Dorus and Pamela, or two feends with their voyces pastby whilst
I was in Apollos tree

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Apollos tree

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Cast off your wonder I am not such an asse, but I perceive We are gull'd

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: So Divell Dorus tould me

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Oh me they are gon, was this your care

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay then where was your owne.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Fall not at odds bout that, but goe with me
And helpe me to scape the gallow tree.

div.stage: Enter Gynecia and Pyrocles, with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Did I not counterfeit an infirmitie

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Rarely, how love will prompt his votarie
The King suspects not what we purpose

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Las poore man, how carefull he seem'd of my health
And councell'd me to bed

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I smil'd to see it

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: So soone as he is a sleepe expect me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Stay, oth suddaine I ha thought upon a way
Blessed blessed minute.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What's the device

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You shan'ot goe to bed

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Not I

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: God Genius
I will not trust our worke to fortune if
You should want cunning in your passions
Or he should wake unhappily and finde
You absent, all were lost, to prevent this
You shall not come to me if there be danger
'Tis fit I be expos'd Ile take your place
And disaray me for Basilius bed.
De'e marke, muffled up for your suppos'd
Distemper, let me alone to counterfeit
Dulnes, and when his sences are chain'd up
In sleepe, I will come downe toth cave to you
But take my mantle if any of Dametas
People meete you

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I will visit bu • my Closet
And follow thy instructions,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If there be any starrs are kinde to love
This night shoote forth your golden heads, be thou
Bright moone propitious; on all eyes that would
Betray our flight, cast out a fullen mist
And hide thy silver cressent in a cloud,
But to our passage be a gentle goddesse
And borrow of thy brother yet more light
The day may spare it, Musidorus is
sp.stage: Enter Gynecia with a golden Violl.
sp.l: Embark'd already with his Mistris,
If I obtaine Philocleas consent

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Zelmane now I am prepar'd

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Haste to the Cave, expect,
Your servants visit

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: And my happines

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How rudely vice becomes us, here's a Lady
Whom never fame yet blemish'd, now the example
Of Cupids tyranie, love transformes us all
And fooles our understandings, I pittie her▪
Now are Basilius thoughts in motion
And hurry him to the same licentiousnes.
There is warme snow I see, he delaies time.
In hope to finde his Queene asleepe, whose place
I must assume for once, love dwells upon
A cliffe and all the waies to our enjoying
Are difficult and ragged,
But I forget, Basilius, I must
Compose me for his bed, I shannot be
Much troubled, good old King he wishes me
Good rest I know, and secure dreames, oh see
Philoclea what waies I come to thee

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: These sounds may charme her into slumbers sweetly
Oh steale into her, hang upon her heart,
Come fixe your gentle raptures in her soule
That it may take delight to be orecome
And never wake the body, till Basilius
Returne with happy Conquest from Zelmane
Or if there be a leaden god of sleepe.
Heere let him shake his wings and then dispatch
A Herra • ld to the silent house of dreames
To bring one hither happier then the rest
To entertaine my melancholly Queene; oh Philoclea
Thy mother will excuse thee this nights dutie
Doe not disturbe her, yet your voyce and Lute
'Ith next Chamber may procure her sleepe
That done without more ceremony goe
To bed, so so my bloud begins to move
Shee's fast, I heare her, and the musique ceast,
Now to Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'me troubled, and dare not goe to bed
There's some thing whispers to my soule this will
Will be a fatall night, my mother is not well
I must needs see her—ha, the gods protect me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If there were any treason meant against
Philoclea her prayers were vainely offerd,
Since h • r owne innocence is protection
As powerfull as the Gods, I bring no horror
To fright your blood, dee not know me Lady
I was Zelmane,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was •

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have been
So watched by your Ielous mother

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: But I forget

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: To make fast the doores
If I could barre all the aire out saving what
Your breath should draw, for should I live by that
You would not chide my care

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If you cannot forgive me punish pray
This rudenes with my death; I prostrate to
Your feete my sword, and call you to my brest
To meete your anger, at this distance beg
I may behould you, but when you shall finde
In the dissection of my heart, whose name
Hath fill'd it, and with what religion there
My thoughts adore your memory, too late
It may invite your teares, can faire Philoclea
Thinke I have a soule that dare be wicked to her?
Such lookes would charme a ravisher, and throw
Ice through a Satires blood, but a man chaste
Already it drawes up to the simplicitie
And nature of an Angell, oh Philoclea
I am so farre from being ill my selfe
In such a sensuall way, that although time
And this faire opportunity might tempt
And excuse wanton heate, I should repent
Forget to, love your selfe, if you but with
One thought so treacherous to your virgin honor
Should give consent to enioy you, it hath snow
Vpon my blood Philoclea, whose flowings
Are Chast as Christall: dare you trust me yet
To kisse your hand, my lips shall gently touch it
Nor will I leave a breath to staine the whitenesse
Pray be not fearefull.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sin did never yet
Prophane that voyce.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: When it sounds lustfully
Your hate, a punishment next the wrath of heaven
Strike my heart dead—be pleas'd to rest a little
And if you dare vouch safe me to sit so neere you▪
I have much to tell you

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I know not what to say, where is my father
I had a mother too, this Chamber they
Vs'd to call their's

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: They are safe Philoclea,
Let not your cheeke looke pale, their absence wrought
For such a minute doth encourage me
To tell you now or never you must shew
There dwells a pittle in you, oh looke smooth
On him whose life and fortunes you may now
Advance or ruine ever, if you can
Remember who I am, and what your vertue
Hath made me suster, thinke me worthy of
A life, let it begin from your consent
To love poore Pyrocles, 'tis in your power
To be no more a prisoner to this rude
And solitarie dwelling, such a brightnes
Is lost in caves, extend your arme and reach
A throane where seated with becomming greatnes
You may disperse with moving of your eye
An influence beyond the starrs, and quicken
A world that waites to be your creature

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pyrocles
For so you call your selfe, and such I dare
Beleeve you are, for falsehood cannot dwell
A neighbor to that tongue although I might
Demand with reason, and my dutie first
What does concerne my parents, such a truth
Shines in your language, and such Innocence
In what you call affection, I must
Declare you have not plac'd one good thought heere
Which is not answerd with my heart, the fire
Which sparkled in your bosome long since leap'd
Into my brest and there burnes modestly
It would have spread into a greater flame
But still I curb'd it with my teares, oh Pyrocles
I would thou wert Zelmane agen, and yet
I must confesse I lov'd thee then, I know not
With what propheticke soule but I did wish
Often, thou were no man, or I no woman

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Thou wert the comfort of my sleepes

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And you
The object of my watches, when the night
Wanted a spell to cast me into slumber
Yet when the weight of my owne thoughts grew heavie
For my teare dropping eyes, and drew these Curtaines
My dreames wert still of thee, forgive my blushes
And the imagination thou wert then
My harmelesse bed fellow

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I arive too soone
At my desires, gently oh gently drop
These joyes into me, least at once let fall
I sinke beneath the tempest of my blessings
And you swell my heart too fast

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: If yo • be Pyrocles
You will rest satisfied with this confession
You onely shall obtaine my love

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Although my soule acknowledge this a blessing
Such as no service can reward enough
There remaines something, something which your honor
May easily consent to in this absence
Of both your parents whom with severall promises
Of my returne, I have already sent
To 'th Cave where they in vaine this night expect me
We must for sake this place, I have provided
For our conueiance to my fathers kingdome
If after all these arguments of love
You dare trust Pyrocles to convey you thether,

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.l: I dare give thee my life, but pardom me
This is not safe, thus seeking to assure.
You may vntimely happen loose Philoclea
My dutie binds me not to rob my parents,
Such a departure may undoe their comfort •
As y'are a prince perswade me not commit
So unnaturall a trespasse, weel expect
And satisfie our young desires till time
Mature our joy, I could content my selfe
To looke on Pyrocles and thinke it happines
Enough, or if my soule affect variety
Of pleasure every accent of thy voyce
Shall Court me with new rapture, and if these
Delights be narrow for us there is left
A modest kisse, whose every touch conveies
Our melting soules into each others lipes,
Why should not you be pleas'd to looke on me
To heare and sometimes kisse Philoclea
Indeed you make me blush

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What an Ecclips
Hath that vaile made, it was not night till now
Looke if the starres have not withdrawne themselves
As they had waited on her richer brightnes.
And missing of her eyes are stolen to bed,
What world of beauty is behinde that cloud
But keepe it still conceal'd, and let the creatures
When they shall misse day (for the same without
Thine eyes will glimmer like a petty taper)
Feare to be lost in darkenes, and expect
No light to follow, but from those wide flames
Which heaven hath threaten'd to destroy the world,
When thou hast frighted us renew againe
Our state and cure againe the fainting vniverse
One looke restores all—ha, Philoclea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There's something that sits heavy on my forehead
I know you cannot but be noble, pray
A little sleepe, if I exceede three minutes
Prithee wake me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Ha, I doe not like
Her sences should be snatchd away so strangely
'Tis an ill omen, I should trespasse much
Gainst manners, to disturbe her, beside she
Did make it her request whose will is sacred,
Then gently may she sleepe, and yet if she
Draw out this slumber to any length my hopes
Are blasted, if I loose this opportunitie
Of flight, no hope hereafter can releeve us
We are both undone, she sleepes still, I was not
Quicke enough to perswade her resolution
So necessarie, yet looke up Philoclea,
No, then enjoy thy dreame, and let us try
The kindnes of our fate, pitty a harsh
Sound should disturbe thy • oft repose, I would
But dare not steale a kisse for feare to wake her,
And yet my loude voyce may be more offensive
Our soules are knit I see into one love
Then 'tis but reason they should exercise
Both the same act, why doe not I sleepe too
The mist is falne already, if I but dreame of her
My slumbers shall be happy

div.stage: Enter Dam • tas as from a Vault.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There be more wayes to the woode then one, she may be in her sisters Chamber, I may thanke my acquaintance with the Buttery and a trap doore for this passage; shee has shut me out of doores of all: vmh a sword I had rather it were Pamela naked, I durst undertake to handle her with lesse feare; vmh Philoclea; 'tis she and this is-no—this is not Pamela, she was a woman, unlesse she be crept into breeches since I left her, no 'tis a man, heere is no tarrying for me; and he were not soundly a sleepe, my smell were enough to wake him;—treason treason

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ha, what voyce is that, who cryes out treason?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pyrocles what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Nothing

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Harke, ist not treason, my sword, my sword
Is gon, we are betray'd, some theefe has been
Within the Chamber, yet the doores are safe▪ ha
Lets see, search every where, alas Philoclea
If now I must be ravisht from thee, how
Can there be charity enough on earth
To pitty me, they die but once who still
Dispaire of blisse; but the Fares twise destroy
A lover whom they kill so neere his ioy.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: COme my bloods since there is no hope of our pardons let us be honest out-lawes one to another, and doe all the mischeife we can, we are Masters of the Woods, and we will domineere like Lords of the soyle; I say we will live, we will eate and we will drinke.

sp.l: Would I were at my forge againe

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Arcadia shall be thy Anvile smith; and thou maist live to beate
Great men to dust
Some of them are so rotten they will save us a labor

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Be resolute and strike the iron while it is hot, where is the little miller

sp.l: Thumbe the miller is cut off

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who can helpe it, be not crest falen, but shew your selues Cockes of the game, weel make the state send for us home, and agree to our own conditions, let vs therefore play the theeves manfully
And so be hang'd honorably

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hang hang ng, we defie the lawes and we will execute when we list in our owne quarters we will rob man woman and child
Do you fight with the men, and let me alone with the women.
And Thumbe had he beene alive he had been a fit match for the children
A prise a Captaine, I see a Gentleman and a Lady strike into a grove hard by, their horses are for their better behavior, already bound to a tree, follow me and Ile conduct

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Without noyse or tumult lets steale upon them

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: This grove is all one bower, nature her selfe
Must be delighted to dwell heere, the Sunne
Can shoote no beame upon us through this Arbe •
Tho he does rage abroad

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The heate betrayes
The Sunne is angry Madam to see you
Whose brightnes takes all wonder from his shine
And leave him a pale starr.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: You complement.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Are you not weary Madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I shall never
In thy societie, yet we may re • t
A little in this shade, oh M 〈…〉
He should be enemy to vertue now
To cherrish one suspectfull thought of thee
Some wild licencious Prince had now 〈◊〉 me
And carelesse of his owne ruin'd my honor.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It were not simple theft but Sacriledge
To rob you of one peacefull thought, if any
Service already have obtaind so much
Trust I am so familliar with mine owne
Desires, that hereafter Ile deserve to keepe
Your faire opinion of me, lust could never
Intrude himselfe a guest heere, I should not
Love mine owne eyes, had they been but tempted
To see an unchast picture with delight

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What's that behinde the trees?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Nothing, the birds are dancing on the leaves
Call'd heither by the musique of your tongue
Those that are silent doe but listen to
Your voyce to mend their singing

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Still methinkes I heare annother noyse

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It is your feare

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: There's some thing whispers

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Shall I tell Pamela

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Pray if you can

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It is the winde that would
Steale through the boughes to give you more refreshing
Whom the trees envie, I doe heare it murmer
To be kept from your lips which it would kisse
And mixing with your breath catch odors thence
Enough to sweeten all the wood, there can
No other danger enter heere

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: We are betray'd helpe

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Ha, villaines, y'ad better lay violent hands
Vpon your mothers

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let your courage coole, and heare us you were best
If you doe love this Gentlewomans life.
Put up your toole, dee see this b • dkin sir
With it, Ile punch her heart, if you but offer
A blow at any of my traine, Ile doo't
As I am true Rebell and for the more security
Deliver up your whinyard to our use •
Or Ile make an oylet-hole presently

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Doe not resigne your sword but use it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold heare me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Let us both die with honor, doe not give
Your strength and trust t'the mercy of those slaves
In humane villanes to us

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: But thy life,—as you are men but heare me

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Drop your steele quickly, or

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Alas she is my wife
Your wife, if you love her be not troublesome I tell you againe

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Pamela bids thee fight, feare not for me
If I die I shall not be dishonord
And thou shalt take a brave revenge on them,
Pitty not me to loose us both, weel meete
Again in death and love eternally

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: My soule's devided, shall I venture her?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ile stay no longer

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold and take my sword
But sweare by some religion you will use
No violence to her
We sweare

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: So first and formost throw his sword out of the way, we have no vse on't, secondly bind him to a tree

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Set her at liberty
And use what cruelty you please on me
Kill me, and Ile forgive you.
Forgiv'e us, heaven forgive thee, say thy prayers

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I see there's pittie in you, if your wants
Councell you to this sinfull trade, we both
Will freely give our wealth, we have some Iewells
Of valew to redeeme you all, and make
You rich if you dare first be so in goodnes
And exercise no tyrany upon
Our bodies, what a misery it is
Such spirits as you are should not have fortunes
High as your thoughts, when every dunghill fellow
Surfets with honors and estates, and vomits
In Taverns what would keepe your families,
But 'tis the times disease, when merrit thus
Disgrac'd and unrewarded by the state
Makes subjects desperate
He says true

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I prithee take my cloathes, would they were rich
And worth your pillage, and will serve me
Alas good Gentleman, let e'en strip him

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: None dare to take a skirt

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Perhaps for some offences you are banish'd
Your houses and estates
For nothing but being drunke
And offring to kill the King
He will not live amongst us as a good King ought.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Alas good men, I doe presume you, would not have kill'd the King in any malice to him
I love the King withall my heart, and a pox take him that does not, would he would but pardon us

sp.l: There's no hope now, we have submitted our selves too often

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Yet let him heare well of you, and tho
Necessitie compell you to be theeves,
Be honest theeves and ravish no body.
And this report ariving at his eares
It inclines him to have pittie on you
And call you to his favour

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Vnhand the Gentlewoman, he that offers her
But a wry looke had better eate my sword
Or my scabbard tho it have been pist in
Faith Captaine he hath given us good councell let us deale
Honestly, if we take away but all they have they will
Have more cause to speake well of us

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Vnbinde the malefactor
Shall I give him his sword?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: His sword thou ignorant theefe no so he may chance to aske us againe for his Iewels; take thy Penelope sweete tong'd Vlisses; and on the next back smother her in kisses—farwell

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Oh, my Pamela.

sp.p: Captaine captaine comebacke he calls her Pamela that should be the Kings daughter,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How, vmh; now I looke better on her I have seene that face in a maske before now

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: We are lost agen

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am the same Pamela
What ha we done, here are all your Iewells not a stone deminish'd

sp.l: If there be let me be gelded

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I easily forgive all and will be
So far from a complaint that Ile pleade for
Your pardons to my father, and he sha' not
Be able to denie me
sp.p: Omnes A pardon, a pardon, if it please your highnes weel goe backe with you

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Not with me

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As we are true men and theeves Madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: We are undone agen

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: At our returne Ile ioyne with her

sp.p: Returne, why whether are you going so farre from the lodge this is the way to the sea

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Vmh, I guest treason, are not you an't shall please your Ladyship running away with this Gentleman

sp.l: He said she was his wife
I doe not like him

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Lay hands on him agen, well thought upon you shall Iustifie your selves before the King

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Dare you goe to the King without a pardon
'Tis the only way to procure one

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Rather goe with us, and, as I am—
What are you

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I am—I know not

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Weel teach you to know your selfe; away with 'em we are all made

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Villaines and Rebells.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Zelmane has abus'd me

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Chide not her
'Twas mine owne plot to trie your constancie.
Death cease upon Zelmane for his comming
But I will be reveng'd, when did I fall
From my high birth; in what lascivious action
Lost I my fame, that this Basilius
should wrong his owne Gynecia

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I am asham'd, I prithee chide no more.
She gave me sure some philter to betray
